title: 109_hr1812
content:
The Act titled "Patient Navigator Outreach and Chronic Disease Prevention Act of 2005" establishes Patient Navigator Grants under the Public Health Service Act. The Act establishes grants for patient navigator services to improve health care outcomes. Recipients must use funds to recruit, train, and employ patient navigators who have direct knowledge of the communities they serve. The Act establishes grants for patient navigator services to improve health care outcomes by assisting individuals in accessing prevention services, involving community organizations in providing better access to healthcare, and notifying individuals of clinical trials. The Act establishes grants for patient navigator services to improve health care outcomes by assisting individuals in accessing prevention services, involving community organizations in providing better access to healthcare, and facilitating enrollment in clinical trials. Patient navigators also help patients overcome barriers within the health care system, coordinate with health insurance programs, and conduct ongoing outreach to address health disparities. The Act establishes grants for patient navigator services to improve health care outcomes by assisting individuals in accessing prevention services and addressing health disparities. Recipients of the grant must prohibit patient navigators from accepting referral fees and using grant funds for legal fees. The Secretary may award grants for periods of up to 3 years, with possible extensions of up to 1 year. The total grant period cannot exceed 4 years and must not end after September 30, 2010. To apply for a grant, eligible entities must submit an application with required information to the Secretary. The Secretary may require grant applicants to outline how they will establish baseline measures and benchmarks. Uniform baseline measures will be established to evaluate program outcomes. Preference will be given to applicants planning to use patient navigator services to improve healthcare outcomes. The Secretary ensures coordination of the grant program with existing programs to improve access to healthcare services. A study will be conducted after the program's completion, with a report submitted to Congress on the results. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress evaluating program outcomes, providing recommendations for using patient navigator programs in other public health areas, and may require grant recipients to submit reports on program outcomes. The section does not authorize funding for health care services delivery, only patient navigator duties. Definitions include eligible entities like health centers, hospitals, and academic health centers, and health disparity populations. The term 'health disparity population' refers to a group with significant differences in disease rates compared to the general population. A 'patient navigator' is someone trained to assist in healthcare duties. Funding of $25 million is authorized for fiscal years 2006-2010 for this program. The curr_chunk can be summarized as:
